channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-2460] fix TestPublicKeyEncryption.java
item.description: as reported by Tilman in PDFBOX-2456

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: patch2460Decryption.txt fixes a problem that probably comes from the port of bc-v145 to the newer bc-v1.50 etc.

patch2460PublicKeyTestCase.txt contains my changes to at least be able to run the test and successfully decrypt a pdf.
Admitted, constant HOME_WORKSPACE is not ready for committ, but I hope it is helpful.
Whether the Assertions are as they should wasn't my focus.

Could you please explain

  • where did you get the idea for the changes in PublicKeySecurityHandler / explain what it improves / fixes?
  • isn't it risky to call match() with materialCert == null? Are you sure that this won't return true?
  • what is the purpose of the second patch / why does the test not work without it?

Re

  • the idea: I have worked on other BouncyCastle version upgrades before and if you step into/look at the source of the match() command, this approach becomes obvious
  • risky: that may be risky, but I didn't introduce more risk than there was before since it could have be null also without my patch, I just didn't want to add the risk of a NullPointerException
  • purpose of second patch: it may be possible that in your setup it also runs without the patch, it helped me to get it running

I can't get it to run, even with the second patch (which I think isn't needed). I have installed strong encryption, but get this:

testProtectionError(org.apache.pdfbox.encryption.TestPublicKeyEncryption)  Time elapsed: 0.053 sec  <<< ERROR!
java.io.IOException: The certificate matches none of 1 recipient entries
	at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.encryption.PublicKeySecurityHandler.prepareForDecryption(PublicKeySecurityHandler.java:198)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.encryption.PublicKeySecurityHandler.decryptDocument(PublicKeySecurityHandler.java:117)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDDocument.openProtection(PDDocument.java:1295)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.encryption.TestPublicKeyEncryption.testProtectionError(TestPublicKeyEncryption.java:140)
Just an idea - could it be that something was lost when creating the patch? The variable "j" isn't used.

• re "risky" even if a "null" were to match, if you get the wrong private key, with a decent algorithm, the decryption should fail
  • as for your error above: have you gotten the source bc*-jdk15on150.jar and stepped through the match() ?
    For me, it matched and afterwards decrypted properly.

-"j" was added to give additional debug statements/insights for the case the RID would not match, but since it did match and there was only one recipCertificate, I didn't pursue that.

Why should I get bc 1.50? We're at 1.51. Anyway, same problem with 1.50.
I can't step through the sources. They are there, but my IDE won't let me step through it for some reason.

The 3 tests fail for different reasons: testProtectionError() fails because it can't match. The two other tests fail the canAssembleDocument() test.

Are you using the files of the trunk, or different files?

X509CertificateHolderSelector does matching work.
I hope the 1.50 vs. 1.51 isn't reason for the different behaviour observed.

What do you get with "patch2460DecryptionVerbose.txt" ?

java.io.IOException: The certificate matches none of 1 recipient entries
1: serial-#: rid 2 vs. cert 3 issuer: rid
'C=FR,L=Paris,O=PDFBox,ST=Paris,OU=None,CN=PDFBox Tests CA,E=XXXX' vs. cert 'C=FR,L=Paris,O=PDFBox,ST=Paris,OU=None,CN=PDFBox Tests CA,E=XXXX'

(XXXX = removed the mail adr, but it is identical)
you appear to have a confusion with the keys - you encrypt for test1.der (serial-# 2) but try to decrypt with test2.pfx (serial-#3) ==> no match

Indeed, that's the point of testProtectionError().

Could it be that you're not testing on the trunk? I see that the exception handling in the test was removed in March in PDFBOX-1973. This mistake wasn't caught because the test is disabled.

as per Tilman's request now also fixing testProtectionError()

patch2460PublicKeyTestCaseOnError.txt replaces patch2460PublicKeyTestCase.txt

Commit 1634926 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1634926 ]

PDFBOX-2460: put back exception handler

Commit 1634927 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1634927 ]

PDFBOX-2460: fix prepareForDecryption() for BC 1.51 and add verbose error handler, thanks to Ralf Hauser

Commit 1634930 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1634930 ]

PDFBOX-2460: keep accessPermission locally after decryption, so that the real permissions are available

Commit 1634934 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1634934 ]

PDFBOX-2460: enable TestPublicKeyEncryption in build

@Ralf Hauser, thanks for your input in this matter. I have committed your "verbose" patch with slight changes. The code is useful if we ever have problems in the future.

Re the test file, I've only done a "minimal" change, i.e. put back the exception that was deleted. This was probably done accidentally, without seeing that it was in a test where we wanted to fail.

Re the two tests that didn't work:
The access permissions are correct in prepareForDecryption(), but later no more, because a default "free for all" permission object is given. The problem is getting the permissions into PDDocument. This was a bit "complicated" and didn't work. getCurrentAccessPermission() doesn't work after decrypt, even getSecurityHandler() no longer works. My solution is to get the permissions immediately and to keep them in PDDocument.

And the best:
The test is now enabled.

Hmmm, looks like the tests fail.

All are complaining about the same issue

java.security.InvalidKeyException: Illegal key size or default parameters

Does the test need strong encryption to be installed?
Yes, I had the same problem this morning.
I've switched the jenkins build to use a jdk called "jdk 1.6 (unlimited security)". I'm not sure if that's what we are looking for but let's see what the next build will look like.

Commit 1634993 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1634993 ]

PDFBOX-2460: add check that strong encryption is installed

testProtectionError() unfortunately lost a lot of its quality.

With my patch, it would only succeed if the code properly detected the application of the wrong key with the specific serial numbers.

Now it succeeds with any other IOException, so a lot of potential for false positives, i.e. the code may be badly broken and the test still succeeds

But the two other tests use the same file set and succeed only if there is a match. IMHO if testProtectionError() would fail for "another reason", then the two other tests would fail too.

What's left is the specific case that it doesn't match, and that this case would produce an IOException at "the wrong place". I'll rethink that.
Thanks lehmi there was one successful build in the night so that solved it.

Since build #1382 the TestDateUtil test fails. But there are no related changes. There were tilman changes (r1634993) concerning the encryption tests and mine changing the jdk for the build environment. Any ideas?
is it thinkable that the new "jdk 1.6 (unlimited security)" is not up-to-date with the daylight savings time config/environment?

Maybe the end of summertime?

Build and test works locally.

testParseTZ(org.apache.pdfbox.util.TestDateUtil)  Time elapsed: 0.027 sec  <<< FAILURE!
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<14400000> but was:<10800000>
	at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:57)
	at junit.framework.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:329)
	at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:78)
	at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:234)
	at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:241)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.assertEquals(TestCase.java:409)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.util.TestDateUtil.checkParseTZ(TestDateUtil.java:365)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.util.TestDateUtil.testParseTZ(TestDateUtil.java:387)

TestDateUtil.java:387 = checkParseTZ(+(4*HRS+0*MINS), "Europe/Moscow");

I heard on the radio that moscow changed its timezone system recently. According to wikipedia (which may or may not be correct):

Moscow Time has been UTC+4 year-round since 27 March 2011, but has been changed to UTC+3 permanently on 26 October 2014.
Oops, reading my own text again, it would mean that the build error is correct and our code is incorrect. However changing it locally breaks the build. I am running the latest JDK7.

Commit 1635211 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1635211 ]

PDFBOX-2460: member var to enable verbose mode

Commit 1635212 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1635212 ]

PDFBOX-2460: improved test to check for correct exception message as suggested by Ralf Hauser; code cleanup

I couldn't find something to programmatically enable debug log level (don't want to do it with a file, in order to keep it all in one place), so I included a new member variable "verbose". I didn't want to have the verbose stuff by default, because it would mean that many logfiles that output the message would include all this personal data, that is why I wanted to activate it only in debug mode.

If anybody of the PMC sees this differently, then I'd can make the verbose mode the only mode.

is it thinkable that the new "jdk 1.6 (unlimited security)" is not up-to-date with the daylight savings time config/environment?

According to the log it's an quite old version of the JDK: jdk1.6.0_20-32
Is it possible to request a more current JDK6 from infra? Alternatively, I'm thinking about just disabling that line with Moscow.
I'll try to get an more current version of jdk6 (BUILDS-30)

Trying to build on my Mac gives the error:

Failed tests:
  TestPublicKeyEncryption.setUp:70 JCE unlimited strength jurisdiction policy files are not installed
  TestPublicKeyEncryption.setUp:70 JCE unlimited strength jurisdiction policy files are not installed
  TestPublicKeyEncryption.setUp:70 JCE unlimited strength jurisdiction policy files are not installed
  TestSymmetricKeyEncryption.setUp:80 JCE unlimited strength jurisdiction policy files are not installed

Which isn't going to work out - we need PDFBox to be able to build on standard Java installs, such as my own. A post on stack overflow suggest that using the Java crypto APIs is probably a bad idea in terms of redistribution and suggests using Bouncy Castle instead. As we already use Bouncy Castle, shouldn't we be using the APIs it offers instead of relying on Java?

Commit 1635311 from jahewson in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1635311 ]

PDFBOX-2460: Disable TestSymmetricKeyEncryption due to breaking build
I've disabled TestPublicKeyEncryption for now, as we can't have the build server broken for this long.

The files you need can be installed here:
http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jce-7-download-432124.html

Unless you live in North Korea, it should not be a problem to install these files.

You didn't read the full stackoverflow posts, a later one tells that you'll still need java.

We need to be able to test the crypt stuff. A person who gets the sources is usually able to download the strong encryption files.

It's a useful test alright, but we can't have this as a hard build dependency, as it prevents building on a standard Java install, which is going to be a huge headache for downstream developers. Indeed we've already managed to break our build server, and my own local build.

JUnit has support for Parameterized tests which can be skipped (so the result is neither pass or fail) based on some code which detects if the test can run. How about we use that rather than just failing?

I don't see this as a headache. It took me 5 minutes to install the strong encryption, it is just a download and the replacement of two files in the JDK installation. It is very important that this be active not only on the build server, but also on the PMC builds. Especially yours, as you do many refactorings.

Java crypto APIs is probably a bad idea in terms of redistribution

We're not redistributing them, we're using them when AES256 is used.

maybe you want to introduce

mvn test -Dskip.strong.encryption=true

for those who cannot be bothered with security (yes - even after Snowden, they still exist )

but the default should be "skip.strong.encryption=false"
As a reminder, not having the Isartor tests active by default is what broke the preflight package twice.

Commit 1635569 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1635569 ]

PDFBOX-2460: disable moscow test until getting correct JDK6 on build server

I agree we should be testing this, but I don't think we have the right approach yet. If we're encrypting and decrypting the files ourselves then there's no real point in choosing the stronger crypto offered by the JDK over the weaker crypto, because our goal is to unit test PDFBox, not to unit test the JDK's crypto (unless there is a meaningful difference in the PDF files which we generate, beyond just the key length).

The blockers for me currently are:

  • If I disable the line fail("JCE unlimited strength jurisdiction policy files are not installed"); then the test still passes - why? I presume this is because the 256-bit test hasn't been added yet?
  • Is testing with key lengths > 128 actually testing anything other than the JDK crypto? i.e., does PDFBox do anything meaningfully different for different key lengths?
lehmi, can we roll back to the old JDK 6 on the build server for now? We can't have all the builds being broken while we wait for BUILDS-30 to be resolved.

I'm surprised, because I got the "key length error" on this test initially. Maybe you tested the symmetric test? That one has only 40 and 128 enabled.

Yes, key length 256 starts a different part in PDFBox.
Not having publicly available builds doesn't matter much, there are still regressions to be solved in PDFBOX-2423 and PDFBOX-1094.
Build is now available thanks to removing the Moscow TZ test,
Yep, I tested TestSymmetricKeyEncryption, well spotted. However I just tried TestPublicKeyEncryption and I see the same thing, if I remove the 'fail("JCE unlimited...' line then the test passes.

Not having publicly available builds doesn't matter much

It's not that which concerns me, it's the fact that we now don't have a build server running automated tests, which is not ok.

EDIT:

Build is now available thanks to removing the Moscow TZ test,

Ok, good!

Commit 1635582 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1635582 ]

PDFBOX-2460: reenable test to see if it builds
I've now re-enabled the test, not to start an edit-war, just to show that the build will work now, to prove my point.

Once that builds we should comment-out the following code from the two tests to see what happens:

if (Cipher.getMaxAllowedKeyLength("AES") != Integer.MAX_VALUE)
{
    // we need strong encryption for these tests
    fail("JCE unlimited strength jurisdiction policy files are not installed");
}

Because my machine triggers that failure, but both tests pass without that code. However, I'm not on the same JDK as the build server.

Yep, I tested TestSymmetricKeyEncryption, well spotted. However I just tried TestPublicKeyEncryption and I see the same thing, if I remove the 'fail("JCE unlimited...' line then the test passes.

That is mysterious, because it was TestPublicKeyEncryption failing on my home PC that "forced" me to install strong encryption. And same on the build server:
https://builds.apache.org/job/PDFBox-trunk/1380/testReport/
What is the return value that you get when calling Cipher.getMaxAllowedKeyLength("AES") ?

Mystery solved, I had TestPublicKeyEncryption set in my IDE to run against Apple's JDK 6 which does have unlimited security. Usually I use JDK 7 for tests.

There's still something odd going on though, having switched to JDK 7 for that test, I now get "InvalidKeyException: Illegal key size or default parameters" in PublicKeySecurityHandler#prepareDocumentForEncryption, as expected, however the "keyLength" variable in that method is 40 and on my JDK 7 Cipher.getMaxAllowedKeyLength("AES") is 128.

EDIT:
I guess this method could be doing 40-bit AES but generating the key from a > 128-bit RSA/DER key?

build passed.
https://builds.apache.org/job/PDFBox-trunk/org.apache.pdfbox$pdfbox/1393/changes

The exception is thrown in createDERForRecipient at the line:

KeyTransRecipientInfo recipientInfo = computeRecipientInfo(cert, secretkey.getEncoded());

The value for secretkey is 16 bytes long (128-bit), but cert is using a 1024-bit RSA public key, which is presumably the cause of the InvalidKeyException.

This method ultimately calls:

 cipher = Cipher.getInstance(algorithmId.getAlgorithm().getId());

Where the algorithmId.getAlgorithm is 1.2.840.113549.1.1.1 which is the OID for "RSA encryption". I suppose that means that the JDK won't let us use RSA no matter how weak the key is.

The JDK's default crypto situation is arguably too restrictive. Now that we have a working build server again I'm inclined to agree that failing these tests is ok. But I could be persuaded to make the parametertized if it's a common problem for people, as the build server runs the tests either way.

We need to make sure to explain the new build dependency in our documentation.
